resources.string: Ways to express the Future\n(I will, I’m going…)
The Future
\tThere are several ways to express future tense in English, these can be the following: \n\n1. Future Simple
I will buy a new car
\tIn general, the future can be referred to with the auxiliary verb ‘will’. This is especially true for spontaneous decisions. \n\n2. To Be Going To
I’m going to buy a new car

\tIf there is a plan for a future action or if a present fact indicates a future event, the expression ‘to be going to’ can be used. Informally, you can say gonna, I’m going to —> I’m gonna. \n\n3. Present Continuous in the Future
I\'m buying a new car tomorrow

\tNot only for ongoing actions in the present, the present continuous can additionally be used for fixed arrangements or appointments in the future. \n\n\tThere are also other tenses for the future, which will be discussed in the following topics.
Gerund vs Infinitive
Gerund vs Infinitive
What\'s the difference between:
I stopped to smoke
I stopped smoking

Using a gerund or infinitive after some verbs doesn’t change the meaning in any way. But there are some that change the meaning, and these verbs are worth remembering.

 forget 
forget + infinitive = forget to do something 
forget + gerund = forget how you did something
I forgot to lock the door
I didn\'t lock the door because I forgot
I forgot locking the door
I don\'t remember how I closed the door

In the first case, the door is definitely not closed, I forgot that. In the second, I forgot how I did it, maybe the door is closed, but maybe not.

 remember 
remember + infinitive = remember to do something 
remember + gerund = remember how I did something
He remembers to visit his sister
He didn’t visit her, but remembers to do it
He remembers visiting his sister
He did it! He remembers how he did it
quit \nquit + infinitive = quit to do something \nquit + gerund = stop doing something
She quit to work here
She quit her job to work here
She quit working here
She no longer works here
stop \nstop + infinitive = stop for some reason \nstop + gerund = stop doing something
He stopped to smoke
He wants to smoke, so he stopped
He stopped smoking
He doesn\'t smoke anymore
regret \nregret + infinitive = do something with regret \nregret + gerund = regret about something
I regret to tell you that we can’t hire you
He doesn\'t want to tell her this
I regret helping you
It would be better if I didn\'t help you
Difference between “must” and “have to”
“must” and “have to”
\tBoth must and have to express obligation or necessity, but there are some small differences:
I must see a doctor
I have to see a doctor
\tWe generally use must when the speaker decides that something is necessary, or needs to be done.
I must leave now
\tWe use have to when somebody else other than the speaker has made the decision.
I have to wear my uniform every day
Have something done
Have something done
\tWe use have + object + -ed form when we talk about someone doing something for us which we ask or instruct them to do. It emphasises the process/action rather than who performs it
I should have a tooth removed
\tThe construction to have something done can be used in all tenses and with modal verbs or with other constructions.
He will have his car repaired tomorrow
I’m going to have my back examined
1. We make someone else do something for us, or we pay someone else to do something for us.
I have my dog walked every day
2. Something negative happens and we have no control over it (something bad happens to us).
Matt had all his money stolen
We can also use \'get + something + done\'. This has the same meaning as \'have\', but is less formal.
I will get my nails done today
You have to get your hair cut
Indirect speech\n(She said that…)
Indirect speech
\tDo you know how to report what somebody else said? \n\n\tLook at these examples to see how we can tell someone what another person said:
She said, “I’m tired”
She said she was tired

Direct speech - repeats, or quotes, the exact words spoken. When we use direct speech in writing, we place the words spoken between quotation marks (" ") 

	Indirect or Reported speech – usually used to talk about the past, so we normally change the tense of the words spoken. We use reporting verbs like 'say', 'tell', 'ask', and we may use the word 'that' to introduce the reported words. 

	In indirect speech, we often use a tense which is 'further back' in the past (e.g. worked) than the tense originally used (e.g. work). This is called 'backshift'.
Kate said, “I often go jogging”
Kate said she often went jogging
\tWe also may need to change other words that were used, for example pronouns.
He said, “This car is awesome”
He said that car was awesome

Either, Neither and Both
Either, Neither, Both
\tWe use either, neither and both when we are talking about two things.
Both my friends live in Germany
\tBoth = the two; that one AND the other one; this one AND that one. \n\n\tBoth or Both of can be used without a difference in meaning though "Both of" is more common in the United States.
We both work there
Either has multiple meanings: \n\n\t1. Either (of) is used as a conjunction. It is used to express alternatives and or a choice between two (and sometimes more) things.
Take either book
\t2. You can use "either" to refer to one of two things, people, or situations, when you want to say that they are both possible and it does not matter which one is chosen or considered.
Either of these flowers will do
Any flowers will do
\t3. used in negative sentences instead of "also" or "too":
- I like cats
- I like cats too
- But I don’t like dogs
- And I don’t like dogs either
\tNeither = not one and not the other. \n\n\tNeither is a negative word and is accompanied by an affirmative singular verb.
Neither of the girls was pretty
\tBut it means that there were 2 girls. If there are more than 2 girls, then None of is used
None of the girls was pretty
\tNeither … nor … is used as a conjunction. It is the opposite of “Both … and …” :
Neither my wife nor I like the city
All verb tenses
All verb tenses

In this topic, we will look at all 12 tenses of the English language. 

	In the following topics, all tenses of the verb will be discussed in more detail. 

	We take for example the verb go (go -> went -> gone)
I go to school every day
I went to school yesterday
I will go to school tomorrow
I am going to school now
I was going to school when the phone rang
I will be going to school tomorrow from 10 am till 11
I have just gone to school
I had gone to school and after that I went for a walk
I will have gone to school by the end of the week
I have been going to school since 2007
I had been going to school for 10 years before I finished it
By the end of 2026 I will have been going to school for 10 years
Future Continuous
Future Continuous
The Future Continuous tense is often used in English as a way to talk about something happening at a given point in the future.
I will be waiting for you here at 9 am tomorrow
The exact moment in time in Future Continuous can be specified by Present Simple.
I will be working when he leaves
The Future Continuous is formed by using the auxiliary verb will + be + adding –ing to the main verb
We will be dancing all night
Will can simplify to ‘ll
I’ll be working here
For negative sentences in the Future Continuous tense, we insert not between will and be and can simplify to won\'t
I will not be working here
I won’t be working here
Past Perfect
Past Perfect
\tThe Past Perfect, also called the pluperfect, is a verb tense used to talk about actions that were completed before some point in the past:
They had finished their work by 6 pm
Tom had drunk coffee before going to work
\tWe form the past perfect by using ‘had’ and the past participle (3rd form) of the verb. For example:
I had learned Italian before I visited Milan
\tAnd to make negative forms we add ‘not’ to ‘had’, and can be simplify to ‘hadn’t’:
I hadn’t learned Italian before I visited Milan
Time Markers \n\n\tTime markers can be used with the past perfect simple and connect (or relate to) two different times in the past:

resources.string: \tWith the words before and after, you can use both Past Perfect and Past Simple tenses, because they themselves build the order of actions in the sentence.
We left after we had finished our work
We left after we finished our work
Both options make the same sense.
Future Perfect
Future Perfect
\tThe Future Perfect is a verb tense used for actions that will be completed before some other point in the future.
I will have found a new job by next month
I will have done this work by 5 o’clock tomorrow
I will have got my driver’s license by June

\tThe formula for the future perfect tense is pretty simple: will have + [past participle] (3rd form). \n\n\tMaking a negative future perfect construction is easy! Just insert not between will and have (short form - won’t):
I will not have done this work by 5 o’clock
I won’t have found a new job by next month

Present Perfect Continuous
Present Perfect Continuous
\tThe Present Perfect Continuous tense shows that something started in the past and is continuing at the present time.
I have been standing here for two hours
I have been working here since 4 o\'clock
\tPresent Perfect Continuous is formed by using the auxiliary verb have been or has been and adding –ing to the verb
I, We, You, They → have been \nHe, She, It → has been
Have been can be simplify to ‘ve been, or has been to ‘s been
She has been waiting for you for an hour
She\'s been doing it for an hour
The negative form is formed with the negative particle not, which is placed after have or has and can be simplified to haven’t or hasn’t
She hasn\'t been waiting for you all this time

Past Perfect Continuous
Past Perfect Continuous
\tThe Past Perfect Continuous tense shows that an action that started in the past continued up until another time in the past.
I had been working for an hour when he came
She had been driving for an hour before she came to a gas station

\tThe past perfect continuous tense is constructed using had been and -ing. \n\n\tThe negative form is formed with the particle not, which is placed after the auxiliary verb had and can be simplified to hadn’t:
I hadn’t been working for an hour when he came
Future Perfect Continuous
Future Perfect Continuous
\tThe Future Perfect Continuous is a verb tense that describes actions that will continue up until a point in the future. \n\n\tThis verb tense is very rarely used!
I will have been working for an hour when he comes
\tFormed with the auxiliary verb will + have + been + the verb with –ing \n\n\tFor negative sentences in the Future Perfect Continuous tense, we insert not between will and have.
By the end of autumn, they won’t have been dating for 2 years

Passive Voice
Passive Voice

Active voice means that a sentence has a subject that acts upon its verb. 
	Passive voice means that a subject is a recipient of a verb’s action. 

Active Voice - when the subject of a sentence performs the verb’s action
I did my homework yesterday
Passive Voice – a sentence is in the passive voice, on the other hand, when the subject is acted on by the verb
My homework was done by me yesterday

\tThe passive voice is always constructed with a conjugated form of to be + the verb’s Past Participle(3rd form). \n\n\tNot all tenses are in the form of a passive voice, we will consider all those tenses that have this.
Present Simple \n\nActive Voice
Tom brings the package every day
The package is brought every day
Tom brought the package a day ago
The package was brought two days ago
Tom will bring the package
The package will be brought
Tom is writing a letter now
The letter is being written right now
Tom was writing a letter at 5 pm yesterday
The letter was being written at 5 pm yesterday
Tom has already brought the package
The package has already been brought
Tom had brought the package before you came
The package had been brought before you came
Tom will have brought the package by 10 am tomorrow
The package will have been brought by 10 am tomorrow
